Problem:
Consider a function \\( u(x, t) \\) governed by the partial differential equation \\( \\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} =  L u \\) where L is a linear differential operator. We inspect the effect of an integral transformation defined by \\( F(u) = \\int_0^\\infty e^{-st} u(x, t) \\, dt \\), which is the Laplace transform of \\( u \\) with respect to time.

Given the function \\( F(u) \\) observed at \\( t = T \\), can we deterministically define whether the intervention \\( G(u) \\) was applied at some \\( t_1 < T \\), solely based on \\( F(u) \\) at \\( T \\)?
Explanation: Multiple natural or intervention-induced trajectories could result in the same transformed output due to the non-injective nature of such integral transformations; thus, identical outputs in \\( F(u) \\) do not necessarily imply identical pre-transform and/or intervention scenarios.

causal_map_integration: The application of the linear differential operator L on u(x, t) directly causes the change in u with respect to time (L u → ∂u/∂t). The Laplace transform F(u) of u(x, t) with respect to time directly depends on u(x, t) (F(u) → u(x, t)). An intervention G(u) influences the value of F(u) at time T (G(u) → F(u)) but cannot be uniquely determined from F(u) at T alone without additional information.
